item.title: Learning to scope (and also breathe)
item.description: I recently defended my prospectus! I’ve spent the last few years of my PhD focused on different problems around value-sensitive design for journalism and science communication. Mostly I’ve engaged in artefact design to support tasks like newsgathering and sensemaking that science journalists engage in on a daily basis. When put together, I believe my work makes interesting contributions to how journalists generate the newsworthiness of the stories they ultimately tell the public.

item.title: A prototype newsgathering tool for science journalists
item.description: This past month, I presented our recent work on using LLMs to aid science journalists in reading complex scientific papers. Here’s the link to my blog post about it, published on the Generative AI in the Newsroom blog.

item.title: Talk + Responses: Blueprints for Evaluating AI in Journalism
item.description: Yesterday I delivered a short talk at Aspen Digital’s event called AI & News: Charting the Course. It was hosted at the Ford Foundation Center for Social Justice in NYC, which is a really pretty venue. They have so many trees inside! And also apprently: birds1! Here’s the slide deck for this talk, made under a certain degree of sleep deprivation-based duress and fever brain. Pretty trees! This was a really fun time for me for a bunch of reasons.

item.title: Two Years into the PhD: Thoughts and Half-thoughts
item.description: One thing I did not (really, truly, practically) take into consideration when I started doing the PhD was how difficult it would be. I learnt soon enough, of course. But you know that joke – that the best time to be in a PhD program is the summer before it begins, when you impress everyone by telling them you’re going to get a PhD without having to actually do anything for it?
